div1.p: Stark presents a paper about the measures taken by Reed and his commission to prove it was the mosquito, and not fomites, that was responsible for the spread of yellow fever. Published in The University of Virginia Alumni Bulletin, vol. 3.

HOW THE ARMY YELLOW FEVER BOARD CON-
DUCTED ITS EXPERIMENTS UPON
HUMAN BEINGS.

In the Spring of 1900, the War Department convened a board
of medical officers to investigate thoroughly the manner in which
yellow fever was transmitted from man to man, and to discover if
possible the infecting agent. The board was composed of Major
Walter Reed, Surgeon U. S. A., and Acting Assistant Surgeons
James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear, and Aristides Agramonte, all
being thoroughly conversant with bacteriology and pathology. This
board made its headquarters at the post hospital at Columbia Bar-
racks, Cuba, situated four miles to the westward of Havana upon
the gulf shore. Yellow fever was epidemic at this time in Cuba,
and exceptionally favorable conditions obtained for investigation.

Many theories concerning the causative agent and the method of
transmission had been advanced for years, shrouding the dread
disease in mystery, and it behooved the board to carefully enter
fully into each theory and confirm or reject. It may be well here,
in the light of that which follows, to state that one theory, the
transmission by a peculiar and common variety of mosquito of the
culex order, had been advanced in the early eighties, by a very
gifted physician of Havana, Dr. Carlos Finlay, and promptly re-
jected with ridicule by the entire profession. The world had been
electrified later by the discovery of Professor Giuseppe Sanarelli,
of Bologna, of an organism in the blood and tissues of persons dead
of yellow fever, which he called bacillus icteroides, and claimed
that it was absolute in that it stood the test of Koch's postulates.
The bacteriological world is rather slow to accept dogmatic asser-
tions unless they are supported by ample experimental evidence,
and only a few bacteriologists of minor fame, among them being
Dr. Wasdin of the Marine Hospital Service, hastened to embrace
the new theory as gospel. Dr. Sternberg had years before isolated
an organism from yellow fever cadavers for which he claimed caus-
ative function, and which he called bacillus X.

It remained for Reed and Carroll, after years of patient labor,
to disprove the claims of both the above eminent bacteriologists,
the organism of Sternberg being finally classed in the colon group
of bacilli, and the organism of Sanarelli in the hog cholera group
of bacilli, neither being capable of causing the lesions of yellow
fever. Armed with this knowledge the board was fully prepared
to begin their labors in a scientific manner. Though the mosquito
theory of Dr. Finlay had been ridiculed, it was thought possible
in the light of the recent discoveries regarding the role of the
mosquito in the transmission of malaria. Calling upon Dr. Finlay
the board was shown the gauzy winged, silver scaled insect, for
which he claimed such wonderful powers for evil, and was pre-
sented with a glass of larvæ to experiment with. Under conditions
approaching the natural these larvæ became full blown insects of
both sexes. It was known that the male members did not bite, and
they were eliminated from further experiments. Confined in test
tubes plugged with cotton, the females were fed upon a case of
yellow fever in Las Animas hospital, they readily settling upon an
exposed portion of the body when the plug was withdrawn and the
tube inverted. The insects were kept for three days with only a

immune, advantage was taken of the fact that many Spanish immi-
grants were weekly arriving in Havana. General Leonard Wood,
Governor General of Cuba, fully realizing the importance of the
discovery and the necessity for absolute proof, placed funds at the
disposal of the board for the furtherance of its plans. Selecting
a tract of land a great distance from any habitation, two houses
were erected of plain lumber brought from the United States, and
at a distance from these were erected the tents of the personnel
who were to participate in the experiments. To comprehend the
results attained it is necessary that the interior arrangement of
one house, which we will call A, should be clearly understood.
This house contained one room about 18x12, and this room was
entered at one end by a plain wooden door and at the side through
a vestibule. Across the center of the room was stretched a fine
wire screen which touched at both ceiling and floor, and precluded
the passage of the smallest insect. The half at the further end,
entered by the vestibule, which had double screen doors, was lined
with cheese cloth. Small ventilating windows were covered with
the wire netting. In the cloth lined half a bed was placed, and in
the other half several. It had been proven to the satisfaction of
the board that an infected mosquito, after feeding upon a fever
case eleven days or more before, could infect a non-immune. Being
convinced that a room was infected by these insects alone, the house
was prepared as stated above. It will be observed that this room
had a common air space, being simply divided by fine wire mesh,
and it stood to reason that if mosquitoes were capable of infecting
a room the person on the side with them and susceptible would
succumb, while another on the empty side would not; and con-
versely, that if the infection was not due to the mosquitoes, the
wire mesh would afford no obstacle to the passage of the infection.
The room being in preparation, and the mosquitoes infected and at
the proper stages for conveying the disease, it was only necessary
to introduce an individual on each side of the screen, one being in
the half inhabited by the mosquitoes, and the other in the half free
from them. Several non-immune Spanish immigrants had been
secured, and the necessary experimental quota was made up of
volunteers from the United States Army Hospital Corps Detach-
ment, stationed at Columbia Barracks, Cuba. The two Americans
to volunteer first, without thought of reward and solely in the inter-
est of science, were Acting Hospital Steward John J. Moran and
THE ALUMNI BULLETIN.
27
Private J. C. Kissenger. J. C. Kissenger was the first case in-
fected in the experimental camp. All these men were non-immune
and were quarantined for ten days under the most careful surveil-
lance, in order to refute any charge that might be afterward
brought up in regard to the care necessary in control of the experi-
ments. Four men were allowed to sleep in the part of the room
not containing mosquitoes, which had been loosed in the other half.
In the mosquito half Kissenger undressed, and lay for half an hour
on a bunk while the board watched the hungry insects fasten upon
him. When they had gorged to their satisfaction and risen to the
ceiling, where they could be easily detected on the cheese cloth,
Kissenger dressed, and entered a tent, where he remained till, four
days and some hours afterward, he came down with a marked case
of fever. The four men all this time were sleeping in the other
half and were free from any sickness. Several non-immunes were
passed through the mosquito chamber and all had yellow fever.
The four men, after a period of quarantine, were then put in one
at a time and removed, and in due course of time each succumbed.
An immune then entered the chamber and caught the remaining
insects, which, when added to the number of dead ones found, gave
the total number originally loosed. The mosquitoes having been
removed, a non-immune several times slept on the cot without
result, and to prove that he was not an immune, he was bitten by
an insect in a test tube, after a period of quarantine, and suc-
cumbed. This procedure, therefore, proved that the infection was
resident in the mosquito, and that a house or room was infected
only from the fact that it contained infected mosquitoes. While
these experiments were being conducted, the second house, which
we will call B, was in use in a different manner, but with the same
end in view.

For years it had been claimed that the disease had been trans-
mitted through the medium of fomites, which term simply means
wearing apparel and bedding. Based on this idea, disinfection
and quarantine have been rigidly enforced to the great detriment
of commerce, and with great inconvenience to the traveling public.
For some months the board had collected the soiled bed clothes,
bedding and garments, used in Las Animas hospital and other
institutions for the treatment of yellow fever, and had them packed
in chests, just as they were taken from the bed, regardless of filth.
These chests were placed in house B, and several non-immunes,
28
THE ALUMNI BULLETIN.
headed by Dr. R. P. Cooke, a graduate of the University of Vir-
ginia, after a period of quarantine, entered the building, unpacked
the chests, made up the beds, put on the indescribably filthy linen,
and for three weeks lived in the reeking atmosphere without result.
A second draft of men went through the same experience without
result also. Now, to prove that these men were non-immunes,
some, after a period of quarantine, went into the mosquito chamber
where more insects had been loosed, and others were bitten by test-
tube insects, in each instance the disease being manifested. This
experiment thus proved that fomites were not concerned in the
transmission of the disease. Nature, in her wise conservatism,
does not seek two roads to attain her goal, and these experiments
proved that the mosquito, and that insect alone, was responsible
for the spread of yellow fever, and that quarantine against com-
merce was useless. Knowing that the infecting agent was in the
blood sucked by the mosquito, it seemed feasible to infect a non-
immune with blood drawn from a yellow fever patient. To this
end a cubic centimeter of blood was drawn from a fever patient,
under strict antiseptic precautions, and injected beneath the skin
of a non-immune, and with surprising promptness this individual
succumbed in less than three days. This experiment was repeated
thrice. Now, how could the infecting agent be in the blood and
capable of producing the disease if introduced subcutaneously, and
still escape detection by any known cultural or microscopic
means? The solution of the problem was found in the work of
Professors Löfler and Frosch on the foot-and-mouth disease, in
which they found that the organism was so minute that it was
capable of passing through a Pasteur-Chamberland filter aided by
a vacuum pump, and that, therefore, the organism was ultra-
microscopic. The board worked on this line, and having obtained
a filtrate from the blood of a fever patient, they injected it beneath
the skin of a non-immune, and found that he presented the usual
symptoms of yellow fever. Now the chemical poisons elaborated
by bacteria within the human being and called toxins are capable
of causing the same symptoms as if the bacteria were present in the
tissues, but the process would cease then and there, as the injection
of the blood of the second individual would prove harmless in a
third, showing that the toxin had lost its power. This was not
found true in the case of yellow fever blood filtrate, for the disease
was transmitted from one to the other in successive cases. This
THE ALUMNI BULLETIN.
29
proved that the eye of man has never gazed upon the organism of
yellow fever, and never will till the optical instrument makers
perfect an objective of higher power than those now known. The
conclusions of the board have been almost universally acknowl-
edged, the only dissenters being a few actuated by an animus
unworthy of a scientist. Quarantine measures directed toward
the destruction of the mosquito will save thousands of dollars and
hundreds of lives, and the practical application of this principle
has made Havana enjoy an immunity never before known.

A. N. STARK,
Captain and Assistant Surgeon, U. S. A.

The tenth annual tournament was held in the gymnasium, Satur-
day evening, March 7th. And although the condition of the
weather was unfavorable, the galleries and stand were well filled
with appreciative spectators. Those present pronounced it an
exhibition surpassing even those of previous years. Each indivi-
dual, in his combinations of feats of strength or agility, displayed
perfect control of his body. The coördinated movements in diffi-
cult hand stands, sommersaults, leaps, and dives, showed a finished
character, and smacked less of the amateur than is usual with such
exhibitions.

The number of contestants for first place on the flying trapeze
was unusually large, fourteen all told, Mr. Grant, of Charlottes-
ville, winning the heavy bar, and Mr. O. C. Shaner, of Lynchburg,
capturing the light bar. The side horse was won by Mr. J. S. Ad-
kisson, of Texas, who in all his work elicited the highest admira-
tion. Mr. Adkisson was also victorious in the flying rings and
parallel bars, closely followed by Mr. J. P. Boogher, of St. Louis.
Mr. E. Munger, of Alabama, easily won the horizontal bar, his
work on this apparatus, for the difficulty of combinations, and
their graceful executions, is conceded to have been the finest piece
of work in the contest. Mr. H. W. Hall won the tumbling event
and the Peters prize cup. Mr. Hall was also seen upon the
trapeze, and deserves favorable mention for work in that event.
